channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Judge Declines to Reopen Case Against Ex-President Kirchner of Argentina
item.description: A complaint filed by a prosecutor who later died in mysterious circumstances accused the former president of derailing an inquiry into a 1994 bombing.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Building Collapse Kills 34
item.description: The collapse of a complex under construction killed mostly foreign workers from Benin and Niger in Nigeria’s commercial capital, Lagos, officials said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Iran Executions at Highest Level Since ’89
item.description: At least 966 people were put to death in Iran last year, according to a special investigator’s report to the United Nations Human Rights Council.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Chile Halts Inquiry on American Who Disappeared 31 Years Ago
item.description: A judge closed a case against retired police and military officers accused of abducting Boris Weisfeiler, who vanished in Chile during the Pinochet dictatorship, a mystery that may never be solved.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.media:credit: Wendy Maeda/The Boston Globe, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Boris Weisfeiler, who disappeared in Chile in 1985.

item.title: Head of VW’s U.S. Unit Is Out, and Dealers Are Alarmed
item.description: Michael Horn has played a crucial role in rebuilding Volkswagen’s relationship with its dealership network, gaining the support of the sales force.
item.dc:creator: JAD MOUAWAD
item.media:description: Michael Horn, now the former chief of Volkswagen’s American operations, last November. He is the latest executive to leave the automaker, which is dealing with the fallout from its diesel emissions scandal.

item.title: Chile Halts Inquiry on American Who Disappeared 31 Years Ago
item.description: A judge closed a case against retired police and military officers accused of abducting Boris Weisfeiler, who vanished in Chile during the Pinochet dictatorship, a mystery that may never be solved.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.media:credit: Wendy Maeda/The Boston Globe, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Boris Weisfeiler, who disappeared in Chile in 1985.

item.title: Justin Trudeau’s White House Dinner Has the Air of a Family Reunion
item.description: The state dinner for Canada’s prime minister included celebrity guests born in his country, such as Ryan Reynolds, Sandra Oh, Michael J. Fox and Mike Myers.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS FANDOS

item.title: Mystery Deepens Over the Death of a Former Putin Ally
item.description: A medical examiner’s report, which found that Mikhail Y. Lesin had died of blunt force injuries in a Washington hotel, conflicted with Russian news reports that Mr. Lesin had died of a heart attack.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS FANDOS and STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Sinosphere: The Speech Yang Jisheng, Barred From Going to U.S., Planned to Give at Harvard
item.description: The Chinese journalist and author was forbidden from traveling to receive an award at the university. Here are excerpts from the talk he was to give Thursday evening.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yang Jisheng, shown in 2013, was awarded the Louis M. Lyons Award for Conscience and Integrity in Journalism by the Nieman Fellows at Harvard.

item.title: Brazil Prosecutors Seek Arrest of ‘Lula,’ Former President, in Graft Case
item.description: The former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, is by far the biggest figure to be ensnared in sweeping investigations that have rattled almost every level of government.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil leaving the Workers’ Party building in São Paulo last Friday, the day he was questioned by the police.

item.title: Obama and Canada’s Justin Trudeau Promote Ties and Climate Plan
item.description: The two leaders announced commitments to reduce planet-warming emissions of methane and pledged cooperation in preserving the Arctic.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada and President Obama at the arrival ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Biden, on Jordan Visit, Meets With King Abdullah II
item.description: Jordan was the last stop on the vice president’s tour, which included visits to the United Arab Emirates, Israel and the Palestinian territories.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS
item.media:description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.and his wife, Jill, in Amman, Jordan, on Thursday.

item.title: Parole for Killer of Chris Hani, Apartheid Opponent, Elicits an Outcry
item.description: Some South Africans expressed outrage over the release of Janusz Walus, who had been serving a life sentence for the 1993 assassination.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: Janusz Walus, the convicted killer of South African anti-apartheid leader Chris Hani, testified at a Truth and Reconciliation Commission hearing in 1997. Mr. Walus was granted parole on Thursday.

item.title: Iran’s Missile Tests and the Nuclear Deal
item.description: Questions and answers on Iran’s recent missile tests and how its actions apply to the parameters of the nuclear agreement that took effect in January.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Where’s My Mercedes? Egypt’s Financial Crisis Hits the Rich
item.description: Wealthy Egyptians have been among President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s most ardent supporters. But that loyalty is being tested as the economy struggles.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Sima Diab for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Porsche showroom in Cairo. The government is losing support from Egypt’s wealthy as the severe shortage of foreign currency cripples businesses, impedes luxury imports and crimps their lifestyles.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Map of My Life
item.description: Why I hoard redundant maps as otherworldly as old sewing machines or outsize transistor radios.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Germany Obtains List of Foreigners Suspected of Fighting for ISIS
item.description: Officials said they believed it was authentic, but they declined to give any details about where it came from or the identities of those on it.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Thomas de Maizière, Germany’s interior minister, said the country hoped the information in the list could serve as evidence against several citizens facing charges related to terrorist activities.

item.title: Chinese Crackdown on Lawyers and Activists Is Criticized at U.N.
item.description: The United States and 11 other countries on the Human Rights Council expressed alarm at the sweeping arrests of activists and lawyers and the treatment of several Hong Kong residents who vanished.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Economic Trends: Mario Draghi Throws the Kitchen Sink at Europe’s Economic Distress. Again.
item.description: The last seven years have upended what we thought we knew about how central banks can and should operate; today’s actions offer another example.
item.dc:creator: NEIL IRWIN
item.media:description: Mario Draghi at a news conference on Thursday morning in Frankfurt.

item.title: Fukushima Keeps Fighting Radioactive Tide 5 Years After Disaster
item.description: A full cleanup of the site is expected to take at least 40 years, according to the government’s timetable, and a century by other estimates.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: Little is left on a stretch of tsunami-scarred land in the vicinity of Fukushima Daiichi, the ruined and radioactive nuclear power plant in northeastern Japan.
